''They are going into submarkets that appear to have been overlooked in terms of new supply,'' he said.

Owners have deferred improvements to their second-tier properties in places like Greenville, S.C., as they struggled -- and often failed -- to hold on to ownership. So rents have not budged, while they have risen for top-quality buildings, said Tony Bonitati, director of the multifamily division of NAI Earle Furman in Greenville, a commercial real estate services firm.

In the last quarter of 2012, according to Axiometrics, average class B rents in Greenville averaged 65 percent behind class A rents, up from a historical spread of 48 percent. A similar spread is evident in other Waypoint markets like Orlando.

These investments may look simple on the surface, but Mr. Lawlor still has an appetite for what he calls ''hairy'' situations -- deals that require some effort beyond a simple buy-and-hold strategy if the full value of the investment is to be realized.

''From time to time,'' he said, Waypoint will invest in ''special situations that are bigger and more complicated.'' In the deal that represents Waypoint's largest buyout effort to date, the company acquired a 49 percent stake in a pool of four distressed apartment properties, with more than 1,100 units, across the Southeast. Although the noncontrolling stake means Waypoint still has a lot of work to do to gain ownership of what Mr. Lawlor calls ''an extraordinary investment opportunity,'' he said the deal ''gets us in the door.''

Also last year, Waypoint, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., bought 198 units in a failed condo project in Orlando for $25.1 million -- half the price paid by the previous investor who undertook a condo conversion, but was foreclosed on before completion.

That buyer sold 10 percent of the units as condos before losing the property, so Waypoint now owns 90 percent of the remaining units. These are fully rented and producing income, according to a market source familiar with the deal who was not authorized to speak about it, but real success will come for Waypoint if it can gain control of the condo association and eventually unite the property under one owner.

In complicated transactions like these, where his investors will receive income while Waypoint pursues greater control, Mr. Lawlor believes the returns outweigh the uncertainty of when, or whether, he can unlock the properties' full value.

Since 2011, Waypoint has acquired at least 2,412 apartments in 10 properties and has developed or is building 518 units in two projects. Mr. Lawlor placed the value of these assets at around $300 million, although Waypoint has invested far less than that by engaging in various partnerships, buying distressed properties and avoiding competitive auctions.

To strengthen its operations, Waypoint last year acquired a multifamily property management company in Florida. The company already had some 7,000 units under management before adding Waypoint's acquisitions.

Another point of departure for Mr. Lawlor is where he is finding his capital. Instead of institutions like pension funds and insurance companies, his investors are wealthy people looking for long-term income at rates higher than Treasury yields. ''There's an opportunity to fill a void in the real estate capital markets,'' he said, pointing not to investors who want to invest $1 million or $2 million, but those who might want to put $20 million or $30 million into real estate. ''That market is underserved,'' he said.

Albert Zdenek, president and chief executive of Traust Sollus Wealth Management in Manhattan, said his clients appreciated both the yield and the transparency offered by vehicles like Waypoint, although he disputes that his clients are ''underserved'' in real estate choices. Still, his clients, he said, appreciate ''having an asset class with steady returns,'' especially if they can ''buy in at the bottom.'' In addition, he said the opportunity to examine individual property deals beforehand is attractive.

Last but not least, attractive financing from the government-sponsored agencies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac also helps Mr. Lawlor's efforts.

Brian Sykes, senior vice president at Beech Street Capital in Bethesda, Md., says there exists ''one of the largest differentials between interest rates and cap rates'' -- or return on investment -- '' in history.''

All these factors support Waypoint's bread-and-butter investment thesis and, Mr. Lawlor thinks, its growth potential. Always a driven real estate investor, his mind is on expansion. With offices already in Greenwich, Atlanta and South Florida, he said Waypoint was poised to add a Dallas office charged with exploring adjacent states for investment opportunities. From there, he believes, states like Colorado and Arizona are a logical step.

But regardless of how active Waypoint becomes, Mr. Lawlor said he would not give in to the temptation to pile on liability. ''The last person you're going to hear about piling on aggressive debt is me,'' he said. ''You don't have to risk getting your clock cleaned to still make a terrific deal.''

Correction: March 29, 2013, Friday

This article has been revised to reflect the following correction: An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about the return to commercial real estate investing by Scott Lawlor, a major office building investor before the financial crisis, misstated the amount of property deals involving his private equity fund that faced financing trouble during the downturn. It was $3.5 billion, not $35 billion.

Scott Lawlor is back investing in commercial real estate. (PHOTOGRAPH BY DOUGLAS HEALEY FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

The New York Times Company

You're the Boss
Business Day; Small Business
This Week in Small Business: Does Yelp Help?
By GENE MARKS
1825 words
25 March 2013
NYT Blogs
NYTB
English
© 2013 The New York Times Company. All rights reserved

What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

Economy 1: Turning the Corner

A Wall Street Journal study of small-business chief executives[http://www.prweb.com/releases/2013/3/prweb10486911.htm] shows some optimism, and economic confidence is up[http://www.gallup.com/poll/161414/economic-confidence-amid-record-stock-prices.aspx?] along with a rise in the stock market. A new survey[http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/19/ca-tmc-financing-idUSnBwk3P2ba+88+BSW20130319] shows a steady, four-year increase in small-business job growth projections, and Rick Newman says small businesses have finally turned the corner[http://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/rick-newman/2013/03/19/small-business-finally-turns-the-corner]. Housing starts (pdf)[http://www.ftportfolios.com/Commentary/EconomicResearch/2013/3/19/housing-starts-rose-0.8percent-in-february-to-917%2c000-units-at-an-annual-rate] increased and new building permits are being issued at the fastest pace[http://www.dallasnews.com/business/residential-real-estate/20130319-building-permit-rate-at-fastest-pace-since-08.ece] since 2008. Existing home sales and prices continued to rise[http://www.realtor.org/news-releases/2013/03/existing-home-sales-and-prices-continue-to-rise-in-february] in February, but a report says it’s still cheaper to buy than rent[http://info.trulia.com/rentvsbuy-winter2013] in the country’s top 100 metropolitan areas. Even independent bookstores did better than ever[http://www.mhpbooks.com/independent-bookstores-doing-better-than-ever-in-2012/] in 2012. Recent good data has economists “falling over themselves[http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-03-20/the-magic-of-3-percent-gdp-growth]” to revise first-quarter growth estimates, but if you really want to know how the economy is doing, keep your eyes[http://qz.com/64294/what-egg-mcmuffin-sales-say-about-the-us-economy/] on a McDonald’s “eggonomic indicator”: drive-thru windows.

Economy 2: However

January’s jobless rate rose[http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/03/18/jan-state-unemployment/1996189/] in 25 states. FedEx had a disappointing[http://www.forbes.com/sites/abrambrown/2013/03/20/fedex-disappointing-q3-profit-sends-another-warning-about-slowing-asian-growth/] quarter, Caterpillar reported a slowdown[http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2013-03-20/caterpillar-reports-slowdown-in-sales] in sales, and even though their ad spending[http://www.burgerbusiness.com/?p=13550] increased 4 percent in 2012, restaurants are reeling from their worst three months[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-20/americans-cut-restaurant-spending-as-taxes-bite-ecopulse.html] since 2010. A consumer metrics wizard displays charts that show that this time around[http://econintersect.com/wordpress/?p=34420] the pain (or economic cynicism) seems to be universal. The Federal Reserveholds firm[http://news.yahoo.com/fed-stick-stimulus-cyprus-rekindles-global-risks-040514319--business.html] to its stimulus plan, and Scott Grannis says the central bank[http://seekingalpha.com/article/1284881-the-fed-is-not-printing-money?] is not printing money.

Online: Yelp’s Help

Yelp claims small businesses that advertise on its review platform[http://screenwerk.com/2013/03/20/yelp-study-says-our-smb-advertisers-make-23k-more-per-year/] produce an average $23,000 more a year in revenue. But small businesses still are not spending[http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-03-19/small-businesses-still-arent-spending-on-online-ads] on online ads, and Cynthia Boris wonders why more are not taking advantage[http://www.marketingpilgrim.com/2013/03/why-arent-small-business-owners-taking-advantage-of-online-marketing.html] of online marketing. On the other hand, half of what online advertisers think they know[http://qz.com/64715/up-to-half-of-what-online-advertisers-think-they-know-about-you-is-wrong/] about their Web visitors may be wrong. Here are 26 tools to enhance[http://www.socialmediaexaminer.com/29-tools-to-enhance-your-business-blog/] your business blog, eight mistakes[http://holykaw.alltop.com/8-mistakes-to-avoid-when-beginning-a-blog?] to avoid when beginning your blog and eight steps to increase[http://www.pcworld.com/article/2029636/make-your-business-shine-online-8-steps-to-boost-visibility.html] online visibility. Dan Norris says you should use Google Analytics[http://inform.ly/content-marketing-for-lead-generation/] to determine if your content is generating leads, and G.B. Oliver identifies a few recent search phrases[http://attention-getting.com/2013/03/19/google-trends-search-phrases-on-the-rise/] that have been trending lately on Google.

Your People: Gloomy

Colleen Stanley says you should stop being in a hurry[http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/blog/broadway_17th/2013/03/stop-being-in-a-hurry-and-say-thanks.html?] and say “thanks” once in a while. Venessa Wong explains why Mark Zuckerberg (and other C.E.O.’s) are popular[http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-03-18/why-employees-like-zuckerberg-and-other-popular-ceos] with their employees. Gary Shouldis lists five reasons your business needs an employee manual[http://www.thesmallbusinessplaybook.com/employee-manual-why-your-business-must-have-one/]. Most workers are not saving enough[http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887323639604578368823406398606.html?] to retire, and a survey finds low-wage workers[http://www.boston.com/business/news/2013/03/20/survey-low-wage-workers-gloomy-about-future/5uvPKZnkYfZCkb0MiLLpUL/story.html] are gloomy about the future. March Madness will cost businesses[http://business.time.com/2013/03/19/march-madness-will-cost-businesses-134-million-why-arent-employers-concerned/?] $134 million but employers don’t seem concerned. Here are 10 March Madness[http://mashable.com/2013/03/18/march-madness-instagram/?] stars to follow on Instagram. The president shares his N.C.A.A.[http://www.buzzfeed.com/nowthisnews/obama-picks-underdogs-swing-states-in-his-march-749g?] bracket picks (and the kid president shares[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rvnevh7FZP4] his). Booz Allen studies the environmental impact[http://www.dailyfinance.com/2013/03/19/taking-it-to-the-hoop-booz-allen-studies-environme/] of basketball tournaments.

Women: Silicon Valley Discrimination

Sarah Barrett explains how she became an accidental entrepreneur[http://www.themogulmom.com/2013/03/accidental-entrepreneur/]. Sarah McKinney suggests 10 ways women entrepreneurs and leaders should take action[http://www.good.is/posts/don-t-just-lean-in-10-ways-women-entrepreneurs-and-leaders-should-take-action-now] now. Jane Harrow provides a quick guide[http://www.awomaninbusiness.com/a-quick-guide-to-360-degree-feedback/] to 360-degree feedback, especially for women. Vivek Wadhwa says Silicon Valley discriminates[http://www.forbes.com/sites/singularity/2013/03/20/silicon-valley-discriminates-against-women-but-there-is-hope/] against women (but there is hope). Peggy Drexler says there are perks from crying[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/03/21/the-perks-of-crying-at-work.html?] at work.

Management: Problems at Quiznos

Joel Libava reports on the latest problems[http://www.thefranchiseking.com/quiznos-cant-quell-their-latest-quagmire] at Quiznos. A new book[https://www.powerhomebiz.com/leadership-management/book/business-lessons-from-shakespeare.htm] offers business lessons from Shakespeare. Ron Ashkenas says there are psychological reasons[http://blogs.hbr.org/ashkenas/2013/03/why-organizations-are-so-afraid-to-simplify.html] why stopping activities is so hard to do in organizations. A new report finds that although the incidence of fraud[http://www.accountingweb.com/article/new-report-shows-changing-fraud-environment/221374] has decreased over all from 2011, 61 percent of companies reported they were hit by fraud at least once. And to put things into perspective, here’s how mom-and-pops fought[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-18/when-mom-and-pops-battled-five-and-dimes.html] five-and-dimes back in the Depression.

Cash Flow: The Perfect Vehicle

Wells Fargo topped the list for small-business loans[http://www.bizjournals.com/baltimore/news/2013/03/19/wells-fargo-tops-for-small-business.html] in 2012. Lisa Girard has 10 questions to ask yourself before choosing[http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/226116] an office, and here is how to pick the perfect vehicle[http://smallbusinessbonfire.com/choosing-the-perfect-vehicle-for-your-small-business?] for your business. Katy A. Limbaugh offers tips for organizing your company’s finances,[http://www.smallbizviewpoints.com/2013/03/18/tips-to-organize-business-finance-weekly-to-enjoy-long-term-benefits/] including: “No business can successfully flourish without a proper projection, planning or budget.” A new financial app[http://finance.yahoo.com/news/unleash-introduces-financial-app-small-183500185.html] will track your business’s health.

Start-Up: Free Online Classes

Roya Wolverson suggests the best age[http://business.time.com/2013/03/14/ask-the-expert-the-best-age-for-a-start-up-founder/] to start a business, and Phyllis Korkki reports that budding entrepreneurs can get[http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/19/education/entrepreneurship-certificates-give-small-businesses-a-lift.html?] an “M.B.A. lite.” Eric T. Wagner says that spending a fortune in time and money to build your brainchild product or service is just one of seven steps[http://www.forbes.com/sites/ericwagner/2013/03/19/warning-7-steps-to-startup-failure/] to start-up failure, and Mark Suster also has thoughts on the biggest mistakes[http://www.bothsidesofthetable.com/2013/03/19/one-of-the-biggest-mistakes-enterprise-startups-make/?] start-ups make. If you’re still up for starting a company, here are eight free online courses[http://www.inc.com/julie-strickland/8-free-online-classes-for-entrepreneurs.html]. And these are the best cities[http://www.businessnewsdaily.com/4174-small-cities-startups.html] for start-ups, according to the Kauffman Foundation.

Ideas: Get Cash From Microsoft

Food scooters[http://www.smallbizlabs.com/2013/03/are-food-scooters-next.html] might be the next big thing. Or how about a restaurant[http://www.business-opportunities.biz/2013/03/17/world-war-ii-restaurant/] that serves World War II fare? Or a beverage business[http://www.inc.com/kara-goldin/hint-water-kara-goldin-how-to-start-a-beverage-company.html]? Microsoft is now offering cash[http://www.informationweek.com/software/windows8/microsoft-seeks-windows-8-app-wave/240151314] to anyone who wants to build apps. British Airways introduces an “innovation lab in the sky[http://techcrunch.com/2013/03/20/british-airways-ungrounded/].” Nikechooses 10 companies[http://nikeinc.com/news/nike-accelerator-companies-announced] to drive digital sport innovation. This entrepreneurial couple turned their passion[http://www.youngentrepreneur.com/startingup/start-ups/turning-passion-into-profits-from-playing-games-to-playing-for-profit/] for arcade-style video games into profits. MillerCoorsawards $150,000[http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2013/3/19/millercoors_awards_150000_in_small_business.htm] in small-business grants. Ramit Sethi decides to give away[http://www.iwillteachyoutoberich.com/blog/announcing-the-rich-life-giveaway/] two round-trip tickets to anywhere in the United States. The National Small Business Association chooses its Small Business Advocate[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/raymond-arth-named-2013-small-business-advocate-of-the-year-198825991.html] of the Year.

E-Mail: Expand Your List

Hunter Boyle and Corey Post explain how to expand your e-mail list[http://blog.kissmetrics.com/5-digit-email-lists/?]. A new study[http://www.marketingprofs.com/charts/2013/10340/email-volume-up-opens-highest-on-saturdays-sundays?] says that e-mail volume increased 5.4 percent in the fourth quarter of 2012 over the same period a year earlier (with open rates the highest on Saturdays and Sundays). A social, e-mail and marketing webinar series[http://www.verticalresponse.com/prowebinarseries] is introduced.

Marketing: More Mistakes

Will Stevens explains how to run a content marketing campaign[http://contentmarketinginstitute.com/2013/03/run-zero-budget-content-marketing-campaign/] with no budget. John Jantsch says that the best way to guarantee that your new offerings[http://www.ducttapemarketing.com/blog/2013/03/19/customer-focused-development/] succeed is to develop them with your customers instead of for your customers. Here are three ways that technology can improve[http://blog.zintro.com/2013/03/20/3-ways-technology-can-improve-customer-service/] customer service, and here are five marketing mistakes[http://www.lifehack.org/articles/work/top-5-marketing-mistakes-that-can-hurt-your-business.html] that 95 percent of entrepreneurs make.

Health Insurance: Three Years of A.C.A.

The Affordable Care Act has[http://www.healthcare.gov/blog/2013/03/anniversary-consumer-protections.html] its third anniversary, and all eyes[http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2013/03/18/care-about-obamacare-then-you-should-really-care-about-arkansas/] are on Arkansas. Some small businesses have figured out[http://www.king5.com/health/Small-Businesses-Pursue-Health-Law-Loophole--199035571.html] a loophole in the health law. CVS tells employees[http://www.foxnews.com/health/2013/03/21/cvs-seeks-to-collect-employees-health-information/] to reveal personal health information or pay up. A small-business owner wonders if her bakery[http://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/20/should-a-bakery-with-more-than-50-employees-offer-health-insurance/] should offer health insurance. This insanely complicated chart[http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2013/03/20/can-you-get-obamacare-this-insanely-complicated-chart-will-tell-you/?] will help you determine if you can get health care. A study finds that the A.C.A. is not causing a big shift[http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/blog/banking/2013/03/obamacare-not-causing-part-time-shift.html?] to part-time workers.

Taxes: Get Help

Brian Sutter shares five tax-season tips[http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-small-business/post/five-tax-season-tips-for-small-business-owners/2013/03/18/bad6f61c-8f47-11e2-bdea-e32ad90da239_blog.html] for small-business owners. Deborah Sweeney says that new tax credits and deductions could help[http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/on-small-business/post/commentary-new-tax-credits-and-deductions-could-help-small-businesses-expand-this-year/2013/03/18/0455a9f6-8fc9-11e2-bdea-e32ad90da239_blog.html] small businesses expand this year. A new Internal Revenue Service tax tip explains the home-office deduction[http://oakton.patch.com/blog_posts/home-office-deduction-a-tax-break-for-those-who-work-from-home-d3063cd9].

Around the Country: Flies, Maggots, Rats

A New Jersey poll finds small-business owners oppose[http://www.nj.com/business/index.ssf/2013/03/poll_small-business_owners_sta.html] a minimum-wage increase. A news anchor reads her own marriage proposal[http://www.buzzfeed.com/jtes/news-anchor-reads-her-own-proposal-from-teleprompter?] from a teleprompter. A huge oil deposit[http://www.foxbusiness.com/news/2013/03/19/anadarko-partners-announce-us-gulf-mexico-oil-find/] is found in the Gulf of Mexico. What “Big Ag” does not want you[http://www.motherjones.com/tom-philpott/2013/03/ag-ag-illegal-undercover-film-livestock] to see: flies, maggots, rats and waste. Stephen Colbert’s sister[http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/03/19/breaking-colbert-busch-wins-democratic-primary-in-s-c-special-election-cnn-projects/] wins a Congressional primary. Manufacturing improves[http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20130321_Manufacturing_improves_in_region__Philly_Fed_says.html] in the Philadelphia region, and the Philadelphia City Council passes a sick leave[http://weeklypress.com/city-council-paid-sick-time-bill-generates-strong-reaction-from-both-suppor-p3593-1.htm] bill. A guy who won’t share his ice cream[http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=4DMVgID-7U0] with his girlfriend is analyzed mercilessly.

Around the World: Panic in Cyprus

Cyprus creates[http://econintersect.com/b2evolution/blog5.php/2013/03/18/indices-crash-on-cyprus-private-property-seizure] a financial panic, but Mike Shedlock believes there is good news[http://advisorperspectives.com/dshort/guest/Shedlock-130319-From-Ashes-to-Reality.php] for some. Inflation hits a nine-month high[http://news.yahoo.com/inflation-hits-nine-month-high-february-oil-prices-095312472--business.html] in Britain and the government chooses more austerity[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-21847226]. The World Start-Up Report[http://www.techinasia.com/world-startup-report-india/] provides a 15-minute guide to India’s start-up scene and culture. Jeremy Glass offers a D.I.Y. guide[http://www.buzzfeed.com/thequicheniche/the-diy-guide-to-being-a-hipster-65v6?] to being a hipster. German investor confidence unexpectedly rose[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-19/german-investor-confidence-unexpectedly-rises-to-three-year-high.html] to a three-year high but global steel output[http://americanmachinist.com/news/global-steel-output-fell-february?] fell in February. McDonald’sgives away[http://www.campaignasia.com/Article/336899%2cmcdonalds-gives-away-5-million-mcmuffins-to-promote-breakfast-business.aspx] five million McMuffins in Asia. This kid[http://twentytwowords.com/2013/03/17/student-answers-test-question-with-smart-ass-humility/] has a point about tests.

Mobile: Should You Bother With Apps?

The C.E.O. of GetApp.com says that understanding the pricing model is just one thing you need to consider when trying to find the best apps[http://mwpub.com/?p=1754&utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=how-to-find-the-best-apps-for-your-small-business] for your small business. But Mariana Simoes believes that most small businesses shouldn’t bother[http://www.businessinsider.com/a-mobile-website-might-be-what-your-business-needs-2013-3?] with apps. In a new survey, 63 percent of consumers say they may buy[http://www.bluehornet.com/news/full/new-survey-reveals-shifting-consumer-views-on-email-marketing#When:20:23:12Z] from an e-mail read on a mobile device, while the number who may unsubscribe because of poor mobile display exceeds 30 percent. Fast Company finds the experience of using Square Wallet[http://www.fastcompany.com/3007277/tech-forecast/starbucks-execs-respond-square-criticism-innovation-messy] at Starbucks is “anything but polished.”

Technology: Amazon and the C.I.A.

Anne Czernek sums up the big trends[http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/195837/sxsw-interactive-8-top-trends-of-2013.html?#axzz2O89Dsdup] from this year’s SXSW, and here’s how a few smart companies[http://www.inc.com/janine-popick/how-to-be-best-in-show-at-sxsw.html?cid=em01011week12day18b] managed to set themselves apart from the crowd. Googleintroduces a competitor[http://www.gizmag.com/google-keep-evernote-alternative/26742/] to Evernote, but will it just end up in the company’s graveyard?[http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/map_of_the_week/2013/03/google_reader_joins_graveyard_of_dead_google_products.html?]Microsoft Office “Luddites” explain why they will never give up[http://www.pcworld.com/article/2030500/meet-the-microsoft-office-luddites-why-power-users-wont-live-in-the-cloud.html#tk.nl_pcwbus] their DVDs. Amazon may be entering into a deal[http://www.forbes.com/sites/reuvencohen/2013/03/19/report-cia-and-amazon-close-to-signing-600-million-cloud-deal/] with the C.I.A. Gerald Dicen has some advice about cyberinsurance[http://www.sbtelegram.com/2013/03/19/cyberinsurance-and-its-applicability-to-small-business-owners/] for small-business owners. Staples releases[http://staples.newshq.businesswire.com/press-release/corporate/staples-new-app-windows-8-makes-shopping-easier-small-businesses#axzz2O5faOETM] an app for small-business owners. Sage sells off[http://www.swiftpage.com/en-us/about/news/swiftpage-completes-acquisition-of-sage-act-and-sage-saleslogix-businesses.shtml] its ACT! and SalesLogix businesses. Here are five steps to create a cool, safe place[http://www.eweek.com/servers/server-room-nightmares-5-steps-to-create-a-cool-safe-place-for-your-data/] for your data.

Tweet of the Week

@MaxGoldberg[https://twitter.com/MaxGoldberg/status/314849841354256384] – I honestly think my favorite part of owning my own business today is having a landline.

The Week’s Best

Ross Kimbarovsky wonders if you know how to market and sell[http://blog.crowdspring.com/2013/03/marketing-and-selling-to-squirrels/] to squirrels: “The attention span of a human adult, according to BBC News, is nine seconds (The Associated Press reports that in 2012, the average attention span for a human was eight seconds). Nearly one-fifth of all page views in 2012 lasted fewer than four seconds. And to add fuel to the fire, people read only approximately half of the words on a Web page that has fewer than 111 words (and only 28 percent of the words on a Web page that has more than 593 words). If you’re still reading, then you’ve obviously decided that this content had some value and was worth your time.”

This Week’s Question: Do you think Yelp helps?

Gene Marks owns the Marks Group[http://www.marksgroup.net/] , a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., consulting firm that helps clients with customer relationship management. You can follow him on Twitter[http://twitter.com/genemarks].
